body:
Oops I forgot to show the output of running `python -c "import IPython; print(IPython.sys_info())"`

```
{'commit_hash': '1c0eb68',
 'commit_source': 'installation',
 'default_encoding': 'UTF-8',
 'ipython_path': '/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython',
 'ipython_version': '2.3.1',
 'os_name': 'posix',
 'platform': 'Linux-3.17.6-1-ARCH-x86_64-with-arch',
 'sys_executable': '/usr/bin/python',
 'sys_platform': 'linux',
 'sys_version': '3.4.2 (default, Oct  8 2014, 13:44:52) \n'
                '[GCC 4.9.1 20140903 (prerelease)]'}
```

Interestingly if I run this command from my home directory it also crashes

```
$ cd ~/
$ python -c "import IPython; print(IPython.sys_info())"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/__init__.py", line 45, in <module>
    from .config.loader import Config
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/__init__.py", line 16, in <module>
    from .application import *
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/application.py", line 32, in <module>
    from IPython.config.configurable import SingletonConfigurable
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/configurable.py", line 34, in <module>
    from IPython.utils.text import indent, wrap_paragraphs
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/utils/text.py", line 28, in <module>
    from IPython.external.path import path
ImportError: cannot import name 'path'
```

Do you have a path.py file or a path subdirectory in your home directory?

On 21 December 2014 at 10:31, Dan Liew notifications@github.com wrote:

> Oops I forgot to show the output of running python -c "import IPython;
> print(IPython.sys_info())"
> 
> {'commit_hash': '1c0eb68',
>  'commit_source': 'installation',
>  'default_encoding': 'UTF-8',
>  'ipython_path': '/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython',
>  'ipython_version': '2.3.1',
>  'os_name': 'posix',
>  'platform': 'Linux-3.17.6-1-ARCH-x86_64-with-arch',
>  'sys_executable': '/usr/bin/python',
>  'sys_platform': 'linux',
>  'sys_version': '3.4.2 (default, Oct  8 2014, 13:44:52) \n'
>                 '[GCC 4.9.1 20140903 (prerelease)]'}
> 
> Interestingly if I run this command from my home directory it also crashes
> 
> $ cd ~/
> $ python -c "import IPython; print(IPython.sys_info())"
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
>   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/**init**.py", line 45, in <module>
>     from .config.loader import Config
>   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/**init**.py", line 16, in <module>
>     from .application import *
>   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/application.py", line 32, in <module>
>     from IPython.config.configurable import SingletonConfigurable
>   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/config/configurable.py", line 34, in <module>
>     from IPython.utils.text import indent, wrap_paragraphs
>   File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/utils/text.py", line 28, in <module>
>     from IPython.external.path import path
> ImportError: cannot import name 'path'
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/7282#issuecomment-67779487.

Yes I have a `path` subdirectory in my home directory, if I rename it the issue goes away. The `path` folder in my home directory does not contain a `__init__.py` file so I don't know why it would be picked up as a python package.

I'm still slightly surprised that `from path import *` fails the first time but not the second when I sue `ipython qtconsole`. I guess that's why the relative imports are preferable.

It's acting as a pep 420 namespace package. This should be resolved when we
unbundle that dependency and require it to be installed, because regular
packages have priority over namespace packages. That won't be until after
3.x, though.

As for the second time thing, it could be the distinction between the
frontend and kernel processes.
